content:
This is a methodology note: it focuses on why the algorithm works, not on implementation details.
1. Background #In power-drive modulation, the ideal duty ratio is not the same as the duty ratio you can actually output. A real system typically has to satisfy at least these constraints:
Minimum distinguishable pulse width: very short pulses may be written but not reliably executed. Dead-time / complementary leg safety margin: a safety interval is required to avoid shoot-through. Cycle-boundary continuity: how the end of the current cycle and the start of the next one connect determines whether â€œpseudo short pulsesâ€ appear. If you only do single-cycle, local limiting on one edge, common symptoms are:
pulses that exist â€œlogicallyâ€ but are unusable in practice, frequent boundary jitter, discontinuities near high duty ratios. 2. Core idea (abstract) #Let the PWM period be \(T\), dead-time (or safety margin) be \(\tau_d\), and minimum high/low pulse thresholds be \(\tau_{h,\min},\tau_{l,\min}\).
Instead of chasing the â€œgeometrically ideal widthâ€, the algorithm searches for an executable width with the following ordering.
2.1 Stage 1: short-pulse suppression within the current cycle #First, check the candidate pulse width in the current cycle:
If width \(< \tau_{\min}\), mark it non-executable and suppress it. If it is executable, proceed to the next stage. This stage removes pulses that are guaranteed to fail and reduces uncertainty downstream.
2.2 Stage 2: cross-cycle incoming check #For the â€œincoming pulse at the beginning of the next cycleâ€, do not judge it in isolation. Instead, concatenate it with the remaining tail window of the current cycle.
In other words, use a two-cycle view (abstractly):
$$ W_{in} = W_{k,tail} + W_{k+1,head} $$Compare \(W_{in}\) against the corresponding minimum threshold, then decide to keep or suppress.
2.3 Stage 3: correction to the current cycle #Once boundary feasibility is satisfied, apply a limited correction to the end edge of the current cycle. The goal is not â€œmake it as large as possibleâ€, but:
keep it executable, keep transitions continuous, stay close to the requested trajectory. One convenient metric is:
$$ \Delta = W_{act} - W_{ref} $$where:
\(W_{act}\): effective width after correction, \(W_{ref}\): replay width under the same input and same previous state, without correction. When \(\Delta>0\), the correction brings a net gain in effective width (equivalently, an increase in effective duty).
3. Why it works #3.1 Effectiveness is â€œmore executableâ€, not â€œmore aggressiveâ€ #Each stage starts with feasibility filtering:
suppress pulses that are guaranteed to be invalid, check the cross-cycle concatenation, only then correct within a feasible window. This makes it naturally more stable than â€œoutput the ideal duty directlyâ€.
3.2 Smoother behavior near boundaries #Jitter is most likely near high duty ratios, at cycle transitions, or close to thresholds. A two-cycle view reduces sudden flips at boundaries.
3.3 Quantifiable benefit #\(\Delta\) lets you directly quantify:
which sequences yield net gain, where in the operating range the gain happens, which scenarios trigger correction but still have zero net gain (still usefulâ€”it indicates conservative operation at the edge). 4. Practical note (personal logging) #For a personal engineering notebook, a consistent record format helps:
Case=<name>; Seq=[u(k),u(k+1)]; PrevState=<fixed-prev-state>; W_act=<ticks>; W_ref=<ticks>; Delta=<ticks>; DeltaDuty=<%> Two simple rules:
Compare only under â€œsame input + same previous stateâ€. Check executability first, then the size of the gain. 5. Summary #Minimum-pulse suppression + correction is essentially a constraint-first output reconstruction:
not pursuing mathematically ideal pulse widths, but pursuing engineering executability, continuity, and measurable benefit. That is why it remains stable and useful even in boundary conditions.
summary: From constraint modeling to two-stage suppression and cross-cycle correctionâ€”why this approach stays executable and smooth near boundaries.
title: PWM Minimum Pulse Suppression & Cross-Cycle Correction

Change the page layout. Switch layout ↻ Lab Survival Rules:
If it feels like black magic, check the waveforms. If the waveforms feel like black magic too, check the probe ground. Try the holy trinity: lower the bandwidth, add some DC-link capacitance, and refill your coffee. If the controller wonâ€™t behave, itâ€™s usually either bad parameters â€” or the motor is trolling you with noise. That â€œeeeeâ€”â€ sound? Itâ€™s asking you to tune dead-time, PWM frequency, or your sleep schedule. If this made you laugh, congrats: Motor Control 101 â€” learn to laugh before you lose it.

content:
KaTeX can be used to render mathematical notation within articles.
Congo will only bundle the KaTeX assets into your project if you make use of mathematical notation. In order for this to work, simply include the [katex shortcode] within the article. Any KaTeX syntax on that page will then be automatically rendered.
Use the online reference of supported TeX functions for the available syntax.
Inline notation #Inline notation can be generated by wrapping the expression in \( and \) delimiters.
Example:
% KaTeX inline notation Inline notation: \(\varphi = \dfrac{1+\sqrt5}{2}= 1.6180339887â€¦\) Inline notation: \(\varphi = \dfrac{1+\sqrt5}{2}= 1.6180339887â€¦\)
Block notation #Alternatively, block notation can be generated using $$ delimiters. This will output the expression in its own HTML block.
Example:
% KaTeX block notation $$ \varphi = 1+\frac{1} {1+\frac{1} {1+\frac{1} {1+\cdots} } } $$ $$ \varphi = 1+\frac{1} {1+\frac{1} {1+\frac{1} {1+\cdots} } } $$
summary: KaTeX can be used to render mathematical notation within articles.
title: Mathematical notation

Emoji is supported throughout Congo by default. Emoji can be used in titles, menu items and article content.
Note: The rendering of these glyphs depends on the browser and the platform. To style the emoji you can either use a third party emoji font or a font stack. Emoji replacements are automatic throughout Congo, so you can use shorthand codes in your content and front matter and they will be converted to their corresponding symbols at build time.
